qas.question: What type of CD is intended to be used in a Consumer audio CD Recorder?
Which is less expensive, the ReWritable Audio CD or a CD-RW?
What plays standard CD-RW discs without changes?
What royalties does a CD-RW have?
What year was the digital rights management published?

plausible_answers.text: United States' Audio Home Recording Act

qas.question: What is the international standard for home recordings?

plausible_answers.text: (a) lower volume and (b) a 3% AHRA royalty

qas.question: Why is the CD-RW more expensive than the ReWritable CD?

context: The <a3_0>ReWritable Audio CD<a3_0/> is designed to be used in a <b5_0>consumer audio CD recorder<b5_0/>, which will not (without modification) accept standard CD-RW discs. These consumer audio CD recorders use the <a0_0>Serial Copy Management System<a0_0/> (SCMS), an <b7_0>early<b7_0/> form of <a1_0>digital rights management<a1_0/> (DRM), to conform to the <b8_0>United States' <a2_0>Audio Home Recording Act<b8_0/><a2_0/> (AHRA). The ReWritable Audio CD is typically somewhat more expensive than <a4_0>CD-RW<a4_0/> due to <b9_0>(a) lower volume and (b) a <b6_0>3%<b6_0/> AHRA royalty<b9_0/> used to compensate the music industry for the making of a copy.
